/- A three-digit natural number, when divided by $2$, $3$, $4$, $5$, and $7$, leaves a remainder of $1$ in each case. The smallest three-digit number with this property isÂ ___Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ___Â ; the largest three-digit number isÂ ___Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ___. -/
theorem number_theory_2811 :
    IsLeast {n | n âˆˆ Finset.Icc 100 999 âˆ§ n % 2 = 1 âˆ§ n % 3 = 1 âˆ§ n % 4 = 1 âˆ§ n % 5 = 1 âˆ§ n % 7 = 1} 421 âˆ§
    IsGreatest {n | n âˆˆ Finset.Icc 100 999 âˆ§ n % 2 = 1 âˆ§ n % 3 = 1 âˆ§ n % 4 = 1 âˆ§ n % 5 = 1 âˆ§ n % 7 = 1} 841 := by
  constructor
  Â· constructor
    Â· -- Show that 421 is in the set
      constructor
      Â· simp [Finset.mem_Icc]
      norm_num
    Â· -- Show that there's no smaller element in the set
      intro n hn
      rcases hn with âŸ¨hn1, hn2, hn3, hn4, hn5, hn6âŸ©
      simp only [Finset.mem_Icc] at hn1
      have h1 : 100 â‰¤ n := hn1.1
      have h2 : n â‰¤ 999 := hn1.2
      by_contra h
      push_neg at h
      interval_cases n <;> omega
  Â· constructor
    Â· -- Show that 841 is in the set
      constructor
      Â· simp [Finset.mem_Icc]
      norm_num
    Â· -- Show that there's no larger element in the set
      intro n hn
      rcases hn with âŸ¨hn1, hn2, hn3, hn4, hn5, hn6âŸ©
      simp only [Finset.mem_Icc] at hn1
      have h1 : 100 â‰¤ n := hn1.1
      have h2 : n â‰¤ 999 := hn1.2
      by_contra h
      push_neg at h
      have h3 : n > 841 := by linarith
      -- we need to show n <= 841
      have h4 : n > 841 := by linarith
      have h5 : n â‰¤ 999 := by linarith
      interval_cases n <;> omega

soln_description:
Solution. The numerator $n \sqrt[6]{n}+\sqrt[5]{32 n^{10}+1}$ is an infinitely large sequence of order $n^{2}$, and the denominator $(n+\sqrt[4]{n}) \sqrt[3]{n^{3}-1}$ is an infinitely large sequence of order $n^{2}$.

1. Factor out $n^{2}$ in the numerator, we get

$$
n \sqrt[6]{n}+\sqrt[5]{32 n^{10}+1}=n^{2}\left(\frac{1}{n^{5 / 6}}+2 \sqrt[5]{1+\frac{1}{n^{10}}}\right)
$$

2. Factor out $n^{2}$ in the denominator, we get

$$
(n+\sqrt[4]{n}) \sqrt[3]{n^{3}-1}=n^{2}\left(1+\frac{1}{n^{3 / 4}}\right) \sqrt[3]{1-\frac{1}{n^{3}}}
$$

3. We have

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n \sqrt[6]{n}+\sqrt[5]{32 n^{10}+1}}{(n+\sqrt[4]{n}) \sqrt[3]{n^{3}-1}}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n^{2}\left(1 / n^{5 / 6}+2 \sqrt[5]{1+1 / n^{10}}\right)}{n^{2}\left(1+1 / n^{3 / 4}\right) \sqrt[3]{1-1 / n^{3}}}
$$

4. Canceling $n^{2}$ and using theorems about limits, we finally get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n \sqrt[6]{n}+\sqrt[5]{32 n^{10}+1}}{(n+\sqrt[4]{n}) \sqrt[3]{n^{3}-1}}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1 / n^{5 / 6}+2 \sqrt[5]{1+1 / n^{10}}}{\left(1+1 / n^{3 / 4}\right) \sqrt[3]{1-1 / n^{3}}}= \\
&=\frac{\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(1 / n^{5 / 6}+2 \sqrt[5]{1+1 / n^{10}}\right)}{\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(1+1 / n^{3 / 4}\right) \sqrt[3]{1-1 / n^{3}}}=2
\end{aligned}
$$

NOTE. In this case, the property of the root was used, according to which $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sqrt[5]{1+1 / n^{10}}=1$ and $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sqrt[3]{1-1 / n^{3}}=1$.

$$
\text { Answer. } \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n \sqrt[6]{n}+\sqrt[5]{32 n^{10}+1}}{(n+\sqrt[4]{n}) \sqrt[3]{n^{3}-1}}=2
$$

Conditions of the Problems. Calculate the limit.

1. $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n \sqrt[3]{3 n^{2}}+\sqrt[4]{4 n^{8}+1}}{(n+\sqrt{n}) \sqrt{7-n+n^{2}}}$.
2. $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt{n-1}-\sqrt{2 n^{2}+3}}{\sqrt[3]{n^{3}+3}+\sqrt[4]{n^{5}+2}}$.
3. $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt{2 n^{3}+3}-\sqrt{n+5}}{\sqrt[3]{n^{3}+2}-\sqrt{n-1}}$.
4. $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt[3]{n^{2}+3}+3 n^{3}}{\sqrt[4]{n^{12}+2 n+1}-n^{2}}$.
5. $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt{3 n+2}-\sqrt[3]{125 n^{3}+n}}{\sqrt[5]{n}+n^{2}}$.
6. $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n \sqrt{n}-\sqrt[3]{27 n^{6}+n^{4}}}{(n+\sqrt[4]{n}) \sqrt{4+n^{2}}}$.
7. $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt{n+2}-\sqrt{n^{2}+2}}{\sqrt[4]{n^{4}+1}-\sqrt[3]{n^{2}-1}}$.
8. $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt{n^{5}+3}+\sqrt{n-2}}{\sqrt[4]{n^{4}+2}-\sqrt{n-2}}$.
9. $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{10 n^{3}-\sqrt{n^{3}+2}}{\sqrt{4 n^{6}+3}-n}$.
10. $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt{n+2}-\sqrt[3]{8 n^{3}+3}}{\sqrt[4]{n+5}+n}$.

Answers. 1. $\sqrt{2}$. 2.0.3. $+\infty .4$. 3. 5.5. 6. -3. 7. -1 . 8. $+\infty$. 9.5. 10. -2 .

## 3.4. Calculation of $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left[u(n)^{v(n)}\right]$

Problem Statement. Calculate the limit of the sequence

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left[u(n)^{v(n)}\right]
$$

where $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} u(n)=1$ and $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} v(n)=\infty$.

## Plan of Solution.

1. Transform the expression under the limit so that we can use the second remarkable limit, i.e., factor out the one:

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left[u(n)^{v(n)}\right]=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left((1+\alpha(n))^{1 / \alpha(n)}\right)^{\alpha(n) v(n)}
$$

where $\alpha(n)=u(n)-1$ is an infinitesimal sequence as $n \rightarrow \infty$. Since $\alpha(n) \rightarrow 0$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$, we have

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}(1+\alpha(n))^{1 / \alpha(n)}=e
$$

2. If $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} a_{n}=a\left(a_{n}>0, a>0\right)$ and $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} b_{n}=b$, then

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} a_{n}^{b_{n}}=a^{b}
$$

Therefore, if the limit

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \alpha(n) v(n)=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}(u(n)-1) v(n)
$$

exists, then we finally have

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left[u(n)^{v(n)}\right]=e^{\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}(u(n)-1) v(n)}
$$
informal_statement:

\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n \sqrt[6]{n}+\sqrt[5]{32 n^{10}+1}}{(n+\sqrt[4]{n}) \sqrt[3]{n^{3}-1}}
$$

$$ -/

    (32 * n ^ 10 + 1) ^ ((1 : â„) / 5)) /
    ((n + (n : â„) ^ ((1 : â„) / 4)) * (n ^ 3 - 1) ^ ((1 : â„) / 3))) atTop (ð“ 2) :=

soln_description:
1. Let \( x = a \), \(\{x\} = ar\), and \([x] = ar^2\). Since \(\{x\}\), \([x]\), and \(x\) are in geometric progression, we have:
   \[
   \{x\} \cdot x = ([x])^2
   \]
   Substituting the values, we get:
   \[
   ar \cdot a = (ar^2)^2
   \]
   Simplifying, we obtain:
   \[
   a^2 r = a^2 r^4
   \]
   Dividing both sides by \(a^2\) (assuming \(a \neq 0\)), we get:
   \[
   r = r^4
   \]
   This implies:
   \[
   r^4 - r = 0
   \]
   Factoring out \(r\), we get:
   \[
   r(r^3 - 1) = 0
   \]
   Since \(r \neq 0\), we have:
   \[
   r^3 = 1
   \]
   Therefore:
   \[
   r = 1
   \]
   However, this contradicts the assumption that \(\{x\}\), \([x]\), and \(x\) are in geometric progression. Thus, we need to re-evaluate the initial conditions.

2. Given that \(\{x\}\), \([x]\), and \(x\) are in geometric progression, we can write:
   \[
   \{x\} = a, \quad [x] = ar, \quad x = ar^2
   \]
   Since \(x = [x] + \{x\}\), we have:
   \[
   ar^2 = ar + a
   \]
   Dividing both sides by \(a\) (assuming \(a \neq 0\)), we get:
   \[
   r^2 = r + 1
   \]
   This is a quadratic equation:
   \[
   r^2 - r - 1 = 0
   \]
   Solving for \(r\) using the quadratic formula \(r = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\), where \(a = 1\), \(b = -1\), and \(c = -1\), we get:
   \[
   r = \frac{1 \pm \sqrt{5}}{2}
   \]
   Since \(r\) must be positive, we take:
   \[
   r = \frac{1 + \sqrt{5}}{2}
   \]

3. Now, we need to find the least positive integer \(n\) such that \(x^n > 100\). Given \(x = ar^2\) and \(a = \{x\}\), we have:
   \[
   x = \frac{1 + \sqrt{5}}{2}
   \]
   Let \(r = \frac{1 + \sqrt{5}}{2}\). Then:
   \[
   x = r
   \]
   We need to find the smallest \(n\) such that:
   \[
   r^n > 100
   \]
   Taking the natural logarithm of both sides, we get:
   \[
   \ln(r^n) > \ln(100)
   \]
   Simplifying, we obtain:
   \[
   n \ln(r) > \ln(100)
   \]
   Solving for \(n\), we get:
   \[
   n > \frac{\ln(100)}{\ln(r)}
   \]
   Substituting \(r = \frac{1 + \sqrt{5}}{2}\), we have:
   \[
   \ln(r) = \ln\left(\frac{1 + \sqrt{5}}{2}\right)
   \]
   Using the approximate value \(\ln\left(\frac{1 + \sqrt{5}}{2}\right) \approx 0.4812\), we get:
   \[
   n > \frac{\ln(100)}{0.4812} \approx \frac{4.6052}{0.4812} \approx 9.57
   \]
   Therefore, the smallest integer \(n\) is:
   \[
   n = 10
   \]

The final answer is \(\boxed{10}\).
informal_statement: Suppose $x$ is a positive real number such that $\{x\}, [x]$ and $x$ are in a geometric progression. Find the least positive integer $n$ such that $x^n > 100$. (Here $[x]$ denotes the integer part of $x$ and $\{x\} = x - [x]$.)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Suppose $x$ is a positive real number such that $\{x\}, [x]$ and $x$ are in a geometric progression. Find the least positive integer $n$ such that $x^n > 100$. (Here $[x]$ denotes the integer part of $x$ and $\{x\} = x - [x]$.) -/
theorem number_theory_61453 {x : â„} (hx : x > 0) (h : âˆƒ a r, x = a + r âˆ§ a > 0 âˆ§ r > 0 âˆ§ x = a * r) :
    IsLeast {n | 0 < n âˆ§ x ^ n > 100} 10 := by

soln_description:
1. **Base Case and Induction Hypothesis:**
   - We start with the base case \( f_1(x) = 1 \). Clearly, \( f_1(x) \geq 1 \) for all \( x \in [0,1) \).
   - Assume \( f_n(x) \geq 1 \) for some \( n \geq 1 \). We need to show that \( f_{n+1}(x) \geq 1 \).

2. **Inductive Step:**
   - Given \( f_{n+1}' = f_n f_{n+1} \) and \( f_{n+1}(0) = 1 \), we can solve this differential equation.
   - Rearrange the differential equation:
     \[
     \frac{f_{n+1}'}{f_{n+1}} = f_n
     \]
   - Integrate both sides from 0 to \( x \):
     \[
     \int_0^x \frac{f_{n+1}'(t)}{f_{n+1}(t)} \, dt = \int_0^x f_n(t) \, dt
     \]
   - The left-hand side simplifies to:
     \[
     \ln |f_{n+1}(x)| - \ln |f_{n+1}(0)| = \int_0^x f_n(t) \, dt
     \]
   - Since \( f_{n+1}(0) = 1 \), we have:
     \[
     \ln f_{n+1}(x) = \int_0^x f_n(t) \, dt
     \]
   - Exponentiating both sides:
     \[
     f_{n+1}(x) = \exp \left( \int_0^x f_n(t) \, dt \right)
     \]
   - Since \( f_n(t) \geq 1 \) for all \( t \in [0,1) \) by the induction hypothesis, we have:
     \[
     \int_0^x f_n(t) \, dt \geq \int_0^x 1 \, dt = x
     \]
   - Therefore:
     \[
     f_{n+1}(x) \geq \exp(x) \geq 1
     \]
   - This completes the induction, showing \( f_n(x) \geq 1 \) for all \( n \geq 1 \).

3. **Monotonicity:**
   - We need to show that \( f_{n+1}(x) \geq f_n(x) \). We start with \( f_2(x) - f_1(x) = e^x - 1 \geq 0 \).
   - Assume \( f_{n+1}(x) \geq f_n(x) \). Then:
     \[
     \left( \frac{f_{n+1}}{f_n} \right)' = \frac{f_{n+1}' f_n - f_{n+1} f_n'}{f_n^2} = \frac{f_n f_{n+1} f_n - f_{n+1} f_n f_{n-1}}{f_n^2} = f_{n+1} \left( 1 - \frac{f_{n-1}}{f_n} \right)
     \]
   - Since \( f_n \geq f_{n-1} \), we have:
     \[
     \left( \frac{f_{n+1}}{f_n} \right)' \geq 0
     \]
   - This implies \( \frac{f_{n+1}}{f_n} \) is non-decreasing, so \( f_{n+1}(x) \geq f_n(x) \).

4. **Upper Bound:**
   - We show \( f_{n+1}(x) \leq \frac{1}{1-x} \). Consider:
     \[
     \left( \frac{1}{f_{n+1}} \right)' = -\frac{f_{n+1}'}{f_{n+1}^2} = -\frac{f_n f_{n+1}}{f_{n+1}^2} = -\frac{f_n}{f_{n+1}} \geq -1
     \]
   - Integrating from 0 to \( x \):
     \[
     \int_0^x \left( \frac{1}{f_{n+1}(t)} \right)' \, dt \geq \int_0^x -1 \, dt
     \]
   - This simplifies to:
     \[
     \frac{1}{f_{n+1}(x)} - \frac{1}{f_{n+1}(0)} \geq -x
     \]
   - Since \( f_{n+1}(0) = 1 \):
     \[
     \frac{1}{f_{n+1}(x)} \geq 1 - x
     \]
   - Therefore:
     \[
     f_{n+1}(x) \leq \frac{1}{1-x}
     \]

5. **Existence of the Limit:**
   - From steps 2 and 4, we have \( 1 \leq f_n(x) \leq \frac{1}{1-x} \) and \( f_n(x) \) is non-decreasing.
   - By the Monotone Convergence Theorem, \( \lim_{n \to \infty} f_n(x) = f(x) \) exists for every \( x \in [0,1) \).

6. **Determining the Limit Function:**
   - By the Dominated Convergence Theorem:
     \[
     f(x) = 1 + \lim_{n \to \infty} \int_0^x f_{n+1}'(t) \, dt = 1 + \lim_{n \to \infty} \int_0^x f_{n+1}(t) f_n(t) \, dt = 1 + \int_0^x f(t)^2 \, dt
     \]
   - Differentiating both sides:
     \[
     f'(x) = f(x)^2
     \]
   - Solving this differential equation with the initial condition \( f(0) = 1 \):
     \[
     \frac{df}{f^2} = dx \implies -\frac{1}{f} = x + C
     \]
   - Using \( f(0) = 1 \):
     \[
     -\frac{1}{1} = 0 + C \implies C = -1
     \]
   - Therefore:
     \[
     -\frac{1}{f} = x - 1 \implies f = \frac{1}{1-x}
     \]

The final answer is \( \boxed{\frac{1}{1-x}} \).
informal_statement:
Define the sequence $f_1,f_2,\ldots :[0,1)\to \mathbb{R}$ of continuously differentiable functions by the following recurrence: $$ f_1=1; \qquad \quad f_{n+1}'=f_nf_{n+1} \quad\text{on $(0,1)$}, \quad \text{and}\quad f_{n+1}(0)=1. $$

Show that $\lim\limits_{n\to \infty}f_n(x)$ exists for every $x\in [0,1)$ and determine the limit function.

informal_statement: Let $f: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{R}$ be a function defined by the initial conditions $f(0) = 0$, $f(1) = 1$, and the recurrence relation $f(n+2) - 2011f(n+1) + f(n) = 0$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$. Determine the probability that $f(n)$ is a prime number, where $n$ is randomly chosen from the set $\{0, 1, 2, \ldots, 2008\}$.
formal_statement:

/- Let $f: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{R}$ be a function defined by the initial conditions $f(0) = 0$, $f(1) = 1$, and the recurrence relation $f(n+2) - 2011f(n+1) + f(n) = 0$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$. Determine the probability that $f(n)$ is a prime number, where $n$ is randomly chosen from the set $\{0, 1, 2, \ldots, 2008\}$. -/
theorem algebra_2268 {f : â„• â†’ â„} (hf0 : f 0 = 0) (hf1 : f 1 = 1)
    (hfn : âˆ€ n : â„•, f (n + 2) - 2011 * f (n + 1) + f n = 0) :
    {n | 0 â‰¤ n âˆ§ n â‰¤ 2008 âˆ§ Nat.Prime (Nat.floor (f n))}.ncard / 2009 = 1 / 2009 := by

soln_description:
ï¼»Solutionï¼½Notice that
$$
\begin{aligned}
x^{256}-256^{32} & =x^{2^{8}}-\left(2^{8}\right)^{32}=x^{2^{8}}-2^{2^{8}} \\
& =\left(x^{2^{7}}+2^{2^{7}}\right)\left(x^{2^{6}}+2^{2^{6}}\right) \cdots(x+2)(x-2),
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the real roots of the given equation are $\pm 2$, and the sum of the squares of the real roots is 8. Therefore, the answer is $(A)$.
informal_statement:
$2 \cdot 115$ Find the sum of the squares of all real numbers satisfying $x^{256}-256^{32}=0$.
(A) 8 .
(B) 128 .
(C) 512 .
(D) 65536 .
(E) $2\left(256^{32}\right)$.
(30th American High School Mathematics Examination, 1979)
informal_proof:
We want to find the sum of the squares of all real numbers `x` satisfying the equation `x^256 - 256^32 = 0`. Let `S` be the set of these real numbers. The desired value is `âˆ‘_{x âˆˆ S} x^2`.

First, we must identify the elements of the set `S`. A real number `x` is in `S` if and only if it satisfies the equation `x^256 - 256^32 = 0`. We can analyze this equation as follows:

The equation can be rewritten as `x^256 = 256^32`.
We can simplify the term on the right-hand side by observing that `256 = 2^8`. Therefore,
`256^32 = (2^8)^32 = 2^(8 * 32) = 2^256`.

Substituting this back into our equation gives `x^256 = 2^256`.
This equation can be expressed in terms of squares:
`(x^2)^128 = (2^2)^128`, which simplifies to `(x^2)^128 = 4^128`.

Since `x^2` must be non-negative for any real number `x`, and `4` is positive, we can conclude from `(x^2)^128 = 4^128` that `x^2 = 4`.

The solutions to `x^2 = 4` are `x = 2` and `x = -2`.
Thus, we have shown that if `x` satisfies the original equation, then `x` must be either `2` or `-2`.

Conversely, we must check if `x=2` and `x=-2` are indeed solutions.
- If `x=2`, then `2^256 - 256^32 = 2^256 - (2^8)^32 = 2^256 - 2^256 = 0`.
- If `x=-2`, then `(-2)^256 - 256^32 = 2^256 - 256^32 = 0`, since the exponent `256` is even.

Both values satisfy the equation. Therefore, the set of solutions is `S = {2, -2}`.

Now we compute the sum of the squares of the elements in `S`:
`âˆ‘_{x âˆˆ {2, -2}} x^2 = 2^2 + (-2)^2`
`= 4 + 4`
`= 8`.

The sum of the squares of the real numbers satisfying the given equation is 8.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $2 \cdot 115$ Find the sum of the squares of all real numbers satisfying $x^{256}-256^{32}=0$.
(A) 8 .
(B) 128 .
(C) 512 .
(D) 65536 .
(E) $2\left(256^{32}\right)$.
(30th American High School Mathematics Examination, 1979) -/
theorem algebra_267327 : âˆ‘á¶  x âˆˆ {x : â„ | x ^ 256 - 256 ^ 32 = 0}, x ^ 2 = 8 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_267327 : âˆ‘á¶  x âˆˆ {x : â„ | x ^ 256 - 256 ^ 32 = 0}, x ^ 2 = 8 := by

  have eq1 : âˆ€ x : â„, x ^ 256 - 256 ^ 32 = 0 â†” x = 2 âˆ¨ x = -2 := by
    intro x
    constructor
    Â· -- Forward direction: if x^256 - 256^32 = 0, then x = 2 or x = -2
      intro h
      have h1 : x ^ 256 = (256 : â„) ^ 32 := by linarith
      have h2 : (256 : â„) ^ 32 = (2 : â„) ^ 256 := by
        norm_num
      rw [h2] at h1
      have h3 : x^2 = 4 := by
        have h4 : (x ^ 2) ^ 128 = ((2:â„) ^ 2) ^ 128 := by
          calc
            (x ^ 2) ^ 128 = x ^ 256 := by ring_nf
            _ = (2 : â„) ^ 256 := by linarith [h1]
            _ = ((2 : â„) ^ 2) ^ 128 := by ring_nf
        have h5 : x ^ 2 = (2 : â„) ^ 2 := by
          rw [pow_left_inj] at h4
          Â· nlinarith
          all_goals nlinarith
          all_goals linarith
        norm_num at h5 âŠ¢
        linarith
      have h4 : x = 2 âˆ¨ x = -2 := by
        have h5 : x^2 - 4 = 0 := by linarith
        have h6 : (x - 2) * (x + 2) = 0 := by
          nlinarith
        cases (mul_eq_zero.mp h6) with
        | inl h7 =>
          left
          linarith
        | inr h8 =>
          right
          linarith
      tauto
    Â· -- Backward direction: if x = 2 or x = -2, then x^256 - 256^32 = 0
      rintro (h | h)
      Â· -- Case x = 2
        rw [h]
        norm_num
      Â· -- Case x = -2
        rw [h]
        norm_num

  have h2 : {x : â„ | x ^ 256 - 256 ^ 32 = 0} = {2, -2} := by
    ext x
    simp [eq1]
    <;> tauto

  rw [h2]
  rw [finsum_mem_pair (by norm_num)]
  norm_num
  all_goals norm_num

soln_description:
Let $S$ be the set of integers $n$ satisfying $M-b \leqslant n \leqslant M+a-1$, then $f(S) \subseteq S$. For any $k$, if $f^{\mathrm{k}}(0)=0$, according to the definition of $f$, we can assume that there are $r$ times where $f(n)=n+a$ and $s$ times where $f(n)=n-b$, here $r, s \in \mathbb{Z}$. Thus, $k=r+s$, and
$$
a r-b s=0 \text {. }
$$
$$
\text { Let }(a, b)=d, a=a_{1} d, b=b_{1} d, \left(a_{1}\right. \text {, }
$$
$\left.b_{1}\right)=1$. From (1), we know $a, r=b_{1} s$, so $a_{1} \mid s$. Let $s=t a_{1}, t \in \mathbb{Z}$, then $r=t b_{1}$. Therefore,
$$
k=r+s=t\left(a_{1}+b_{1}\right),
$$

hence $k \geqslant a_{1}+b_{1}$.
On the other hand, for $a_{1}+b_{1}(0)$, there exist $r_{1}, s_{1} \in \mathbb{Z}$, such that $a_{1}+b_{1}=r_{1}+s$, and
$$
f^{a_{1}+b_{1}}(0)=a r_{1}-b s_{1} \text {. }
$$

Thus,
$$
f^{a_{1}+b_{1}}(0)=\left(a_{1}-s_{1}\right)(a+b) .
$$

Since $0 \in S, f(S) \subseteq S$, it follows that $f^{a_{1}+b_{1}}(0) \in S$. In $S$, the only number that is a multiple of $a+b$ is 0, hence $f^{a_{1}+b_{1}}(0)=0$.

The above discussion shows that the smallest positive integer $k$ is $a_{1}+b_{1}$, i.e.,
$$
k=\frac{a+b}{(a, b)} .
$$
informal_statement: 13. (Norway 1) Let $a, b$ be integers, $1 \leqslant a \leqslant b, M=\left[\frac{a+b}{2}\right]$. Define $f: Z \rightarrow Z$ as $f(n)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}n+a, & n<M \\ n-b, & n \geqslant M .\end{array}\right.$ Let $f^{1}(n)=f(n) ; f^{1+1}(n)=f\left(f^{1}(n)\right), i=1$, $2, \cdots$. Find the smallest positive integer $k$, such that $f^{k}(0)=0$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset

/- 13. (Norway 1) Let $a, b$ be integers, $1 \leqslant a \leqslant b, M=\left[\frac{a+b}{2}\right]$. Define $f: Z \rightarrow Z$ as $f(n)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}n+a, & n<M \\ n-b, & n \geqslant M .\end{array}\right.$ Let $f^{1}(n)=f(n) ; f^{1+1}(n)=f\left(f^{1}(n)\right), i=1$, $2, \cdots$. Find the smallest positive integer $k$, such that $f^{k}(0)=0$. -/
theorem number_theory_306499 {a b : â„¤} (ha : 1 â‰¤ a) (hb : a â‰¤ b)
    (f : â„¤ â†’ â„¤) (hf : âˆ€ n, f n = if n < (a + b) / 2 then n + a else n - b)
    (k : â„•) (hk : 0 < k) :
    f^[k] 0 = 0 â†” k = (a + b) / Int.gcd a b := by

soln_description:
1. **Assume the contrary**: Suppose that \(\min\limits_{n \neq k} |\sin n - \sin k| \geq \frac{2}{N}\). This means that for any two distinct integers \(n\) and \(k\) within the range \(1 \leq n, k \leq N+1\), we have \(|\sin n - \sin k| \geq \frac{2}{N}\).

2. **Permutation and ordering**: Let \(p\) be a permutation of the set \(\{1, 2, \ldots, N+1\}\) such that \(\sin p(1) \leq \sin p(2) \leq \cdots \leq \sin p(N+1)\). This permutation arranges the values \(\sin 1, \sin 2, \ldots, \sin (N+1)\) in increasing order.

3. **Difference between consecutive terms**: For any integer \(i\) with \(1 \leq i \leq N\), we have:
   \[
   |\sin p(i+1) - \sin p(i)| \geq \frac{2}{N}
   \]
   Since \(\sin p(i) \leq \sin p(i+1)\), it follows that:
   \[
   \sin p(i+1) - \sin p(i) \geq \frac{2}{N}
   \]

4. **Summing the differences**: Summing the differences from \(i = 1\) to \(i = N\), we get:
   \[
   \sin p(N+1) - \sin p(1) = \sum_{i=1}^N (\sin p(i+1) - \sin p(i)) \geq \sum_{i=1}^N \frac{2}{N} = N \cdot \frac{2}{N} = 2
   \]

5. **Contradiction**: However, this result is impossible because \(\sin p(N+1) < 1\) and \(\sin p(1) > -1\). Therefore:
   \[
   \sin p(N+1) - \sin p(1) < 1 - (-1) = 2
   \]
   This contradicts our earlier conclusion that \(\sin p(N+1) - \sin p(1) \geq 2\).

6. **Conclusion**: Since our assumption that \(\min\limits_{n \neq k} |\sin n - \sin k| \geq \frac{2}{N}\) leads to a contradiction, it must be false. Therefore, we conclude that:
   \[
   \min\limits_{n \neq k} |\sin n - \sin k| < \frac{2}{N}
   \]

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: Let $n$ and $k$ be positive integers such that $1 \leq n \leq N+1$, $1 \leq k \leq N+1$. Show that: \[ \min_{n \neq k} |\sin n - \sin k| < \frac{2}{N}. \]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Let $n$ and $k$ be positive integers such that $1 \leq n \leq N+1$, $1 \leq k \leq N+1$. Show that: \[ \min_{n \neq k} |\sin n - \sin k| < \frac{2}{N}. \] -/
theorem inequalities_85109 {N : â„•} (hN : 0 < N) :
  âˆƒ n k : â„•, 1 â‰¤ n âˆ§ n â‰¤ N + 1 âˆ§ 1 â‰¤ k âˆ§ k â‰¤ N + 1 âˆ§ n â‰  k âˆ§ |sin n - sin k| < 2 / N := by

theorem algebra_278306 {a b : â„} (ha : a â‰  0) (hb : b â‰  0)

soln_description:
Prove (1) $F(0)=c, F(-1)=a-b+c, F(1)=a-b+c$, so
$$F(x)=\frac{x(x-1)}{2} F(-1)-\left(x^{2}-1\right) F(0)+\frac{x(x+1)}{2} F(1),$$

Hence $2|F(x)|=|x(x-1)| \cdot|F(-1)|+2\left|x^{2}-1\right| \cdot|F(0)|$
$$\begin{aligned}
& +|x(x+1)| \cdot|F(1)| \\
\leqslant & |x(x-1)|+2\left|x^{2}-1\right|+|x(x+1)|
\end{aligned}$$

For $|x| \leqslant 1$, we have $0 \leqslant 1+x \leqslant 2,0 \leqslant 1-x \leqslant 2,0 \leqslant 1-x^{2} \leqslant 1$, thus
$$2|F(x)| \leqslant|x|(1-x)+2\left|x^{2}-1\right|+|x|(1+x)=2\left(|x|+1-|x|^{2}\right)$$

That is $|F(x)| \leqslant|x|+1-|x|^{2}=-\left(|x|-\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}+\frac{5}{4} \leqslant \frac{5}{4}$.
(2) By the given conditions $|F(0)|=|c| \leqslant 1,|F(-1)|=|a-b+c| \leqslant 1$, $|F(1)|=|a+b+c| \leqslant 1$, since
$$c x^{2}+b x+a=c\left(x^{2}-1\right)+(a+b+c) \cdot \frac{1+x}{2}+(a-b+c) \cdot \frac{1-x}{2}$$

Therefore, for any $|x| \leqslant 1$ we have
$$\begin{aligned}
\left|c x^{2}+b x+a\right|= & |c| \cdot\left|\left(x^{2}-1\right)\right|+|a+b+c| \cdot\left|\frac{1+x}{2}\right| \\
& \left.+|a-b+c| \cdot \left|\frac{1-x}{2}\right| \right. \\
\leqslant & \left|\left(x^{2}-1\right)\right|+\left|\frac{1+x}{2}\right|+\left|\frac{1-x}{2}\right| \\
\leqslant & \left(1-x^{2}\right)+\frac{1+x}{2}+\frac{1-x}{2} \\
= & 2-x^{2} \leqslant 2
\end{aligned}$$

That is $|G(x)| \leqslant 2$.
informal_statement: Example 5 Given the functions $F(x)=a x^{2}+b x+c$ and $G(x)=c x^{2}+b x+a$, where $|F(0)| \leqslant 1,|F(1)| \leqslant 1,|F(-1)| \leqslant 1$, prove that for $|x| \leqslant 1$, we have $|F(x)| \leqslant \frac{5}{4},|G(x)| \leqslant 2$. (26th IMO Shortlist)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 5 Given the functions $F(x)=a x^{2}+b x+c$ and $G(x)=c x^{2}+b x+a$, where $|F(0)| \leqslant 1,|F(1)| \leqslant 1,|F(-1)| \leqslant 1$, prove that for $|x| \leqslant 1$, we have $|F(x)| \leqslant \frac{5}{4},|G(x)| \leqslant 2$. (26th IMO Shortlist) -/
theorem algebra_602670 {a b c : â„} (ha : |a * 0 ^ 2 + b * 0 + c| â‰¤ 1)
    (hb : |a * 1 ^ 2 + b * 1 + c| â‰¤ 1) (hc : |a * (-1) ^ 2 + b * (-1) + c| â‰¤ 1)
    (F G : â„ â†’ â„) (hF : F = fun x => a * x ^ 2 + b * x + c)
    (hG : G = fun x => c * x ^ 2 + b * x + a) :
    âˆ€ x, |x| â‰¤ 1 â†’ |F x| â‰¤ 5 / 4 âˆ§ |G x| â‰¤ 2 := by

Each exterior angle is $40^{\circ}$ (adj. $\angle$ s on st. line)
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\frac{360^{\circ}}{n}=40^{\circ} \\
n=9 \\

\Rightarrow b=3 \\
f(x)=c x^{3}-3 x+x-1 \\
f(-1)=-c+3-1-1=-7 \\
c=8 \\
x+\frac{1}{x}=8 \\

$$

theorem algebra_195174 {n : â„•} (hn : n > 2) (h : (n - 2) * 180 / n = 140) :
    n = 9 := by

soln_description:
285. By dividing by $\boldsymbol{y}^{3}$, we reduce the given equation to

$$
a\left(\frac{x}{y}\right)^{3}+b\left(\frac{x}{y}\right)^{2}+b\left(\frac{x}{y}\right)+a=0
$$

This is a symmetric equation that is easily solvable.
informal_statement:
285. Show that the equation

$$
a x^{3}+b x^{2} y+b x y^{2}+a y^{3}=0
$$

allows determining the ratio $\frac{x}{y}$ of the unknowns.
informal_proof:
Let $a$ and $b$ be real numbers. We are given the following assumptions:
1.  $a \neq 0$.
2.  For any real numbers $x$ and $y$, if the equation $a x^{3}+b x^{2} y+b x y^{2}+a y^{3}=0$ holds, then the ratio $x / y$ must be equal to $1/2$.

The goal is to prove the proposition `True`.

By definition, the proposition `True` is a statement that is always valid in classical logic. Its truth is axiomatic and does not depend on any preceding assumptions or context. Therefore, regardless of the given hypotheses about $a$, $b$, $x$, and $y$, the statement `True` holds.

Thus, the theorem is proved.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 285. Show that the equation

$$
a x^{3}+b x^{2} y+b x y^{2}+a y^{3}=0
$$

allows determining the ratio $\frac{x}{y}$ of the unknowns. -/
theorem algebra_244341 {a b : â„} (ha : a â‰  0) (h : âˆ€ x y, a * x ^ 3 + b * x ^ 2 * y + b * x * y ^ 2 + a * y ^ 3 = 0 â†’ x / y = 1 / 2) :
    True := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_244341 {a b : â„} (ha : a â‰  0) (h : âˆ€ x y, a * x ^ 3 + b * x ^ 2 * y + b * x * y ^ 2 + a * y ^ 3 = 0 â†’ x / y = 1 / 2) :
    True := by
  trivial

soln_description:
Answer: $f_{2023}\left(\frac{\pi}{6}\right)=6$.

Solution. It is easy to compute: $f_{3}(x)=f_{0}(x)$, therefore $f_{2023}(x)=f_{1}(x)=$ $\frac{9}{3-3 \sin x}$. Consequently, $f_{2023}\left(\frac{\pi}{6}\right)=6$.

Remark. One can immediately compute the values of the functions at the given point. This results in a cyclic sequence

$$
f_{0}\left(\frac{\pi}{6}\right)=\frac{3}{2} ; f_{1}\left(\frac{\pi}{6}\right)=6 ; f_{2}\left(\frac{\pi}{6}\right)=-3 ; f_{3}\left(\frac{\pi}{6}\right)=\frac{3}{2} ; \ldots
$$

Grading criteria. Full solution - 12 points. The relation $f_{3}(x)=f_{0}(x)$ is found - 7 points, the equality $f_{2023}(x)=f_{1}(x)$ is found - another 4 points. Calculation errors - minus 1 point.
informal_statement:
3. (12 points) The sequence of functions is defined by the formulas

$$
f_{0}(x)=3 \sin x, f_{n+1}(x)=\frac{9}{3-f_{n}(x)}
$$

for any integer $n \geq 0$. Find $f_{2023}\left(\frac{\pi}{6}\right)$.
informal_proof:
Let the sequence of functions $f_n(x)$ be defined by $f_0(x) = 3 \sin x$ and $f_{n+1}(x) = \frac{9}{3-f_n(x)}$ for $n \ge 0$. We wish to find the value of $f_{2023}(\frac{\pi}{6})$.

First, we compute the first few terms of the sequence of values at $x = \frac{\pi}{6}$.

1.  For $n=0$:
    $f_0(\frac{\pi}{6}) = 3 \sin(\frac{\pi}{6})$. Since $\sin(\frac{\pi}{6}) = \frac{1}{2}$, we have $f_0(\frac{\pi}{6}) = 3 \cdot \frac{1}{2} = \frac{3}{2}$.

2.  For $n=1$:
    $f_1(\frac{\pi}{6}) = \frac{9}{3 - f_0(\frac{\pi}{6})} = \frac{9}{3 - \frac{3}{2}} = \frac{9}{\frac{3}{2}} = 6$.

3.  For $n=2$:
    $f_2(\frac{\pi}{6}) = \frac{9}{3 - f_1(\frac{\pi}{6})} = \frac{9}{3 - 6} = \frac{9}{-3} = -3$.

4.  For $n=3$:
    $f_3(\frac{\pi}{6}) = \frac{9}{3 - f_2(\frac{\pi}{6})} = \frac{9}{3 - (-3)} = \frac{9}{6} = \frac{3}{2}$.

Since $f_3(\frac{\pi}{6}) = f_0(\frac{\pi}{6})$, the sequence of values is periodic with period 3. The values are $\frac{3}{2}, 6, -3, \frac{3}{2}, 6, -3, \dots$.

To formalize this for our specific goal, we will prove by induction that for any non-negative integer $k$, $f_{3k+1}(\frac{\pi}{6}) = 6$.

**Base Case:** For $k=0$, we need to show that $f_{3(0)+1}(\frac{\pi}{6}) = f_1(\frac{\pi}{6}) = 6$. As calculated above, this is true.

**Inductive Step:** Assume that for some non-negative integer $k$, $f_{3k+1}(\frac{\pi}{6}) = 6$. We must show that $f_{3(k+1)+1}(\frac{\pi}{6}) = 6$.

The index is $3(k+1)+1 = 3k+3+1 = 3k+4$. We evaluate $f_{3k+4}(\frac{\pi}{6})$ by applying the recursive definition three times:
\begin{align*}
f_{3k+4}\left(\frac{\pi}{6}\right) &= \frac{9}{3 - f_{3k+3}(\frac{\pi}{6})} \\
&= \frac{9}{3 - \left(\frac{9}{3 - f_{3k+2}(\frac{\pi}{6})}\right)} \\
&= \frac{9}{3 - \left(\frac{9}{3 - \left(\frac{9}{3 - f_{3k+1}(\frac{\pi}{6})}\right)}\right)}
\end{align*}
By the inductive hypothesis, we know $f_{3k+1}(\frac{\pi}{6}) = 6$. Substituting this value into the expression:
\begin{align*}
f_{3k+4}\left(\frac{\pi}{6}\right) &= \frac{9}{3 - \left(\frac{9}{3 - \left(\frac{9}{3 - 6}\right)}\right)} \\
&= \frac{9}{3 - \left(\frac{9}{3 - \left(\frac{9}{-3}\right)}\right)} \\
&= \frac{9}{3 - \left(\frac{9}{3 - (-3)}\right)} \\
&= \frac{9}{3 - \left(\frac{9}{6}\right)} \\
&= \frac{9}{3 - \frac{3}{2}} \\
&= \frac{9}{\frac{3}{2}} \\
&= 6
\end{align*}
This completes the inductive step. Thus, $f_{3k+1}(\frac{\pi}{6}) = 6$ for all $k \ge 0$.

Finally, we need to evaluate $f_{2023}(\frac{\pi}{6})$. We observe that the index 2023 can be written in the form $3k+1$:
$$2023 = 3 \times 674 + 1$$
Therefore, by our proven result with $k=674$, we have:
$$f_{2023}\left(\frac{\pi}{6}\right) = f_{3(674)+1}\left(\frac{\pi}{6}\right) = 6$$
This concludes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 3. (12 points) The sequence of functions is defined by the formulas

$$
f_{0}(x)=3 \sin x, f_{n+1}(x)=\frac{9}{3-f_{n}(x)}
$$

for any integer $n \geq 0$. Find $f_{2023}\left(\frac{\pi}{6}\right)$. -/
theorem algebra_174850 {f : â„• â†’ â„ â†’ â„}
  (hf0 : âˆ€ x, f 0 x = 3 * sin x)
  (hfn : âˆ€ n x, f (n + 1) x = 9 / (3 - f n x)) :
  f 2023 (Ï€ / 6) = 6 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

theorem algebra_174850 {f : â„• â†’ â„ â†’ â„}
  (hf0 : âˆ€ x, f 0 x = 3 * sin x)
  (hfn : âˆ€ n x, f (n + 1) x = 9 / (3 - f n x)) :
  f 2023 (Ï€ / 6) = 6 := by

  have h1 : f 0 (Ï€ / 6) = 3 / 2 := by
    rw [hf0]
    have h2 : sin (Ï€ / 6) = 1 / 2 := sin_pi_div_six
    rw [h2]
    norm_num

  have h2 : f 1 (Ï€ / 6) = 6 := by
    rw [hfn 0 (Ï€ / 6), h1]
    norm_num

  have h3 : f 2 (Ï€ / 6) = -3 := by
    rw [hfn 1 (Ï€ / 6), h2]
    norm_num

  have h4 : f 3 (Ï€ / 6) = 3 / 2 := by
    rw [hfn 2 (Ï€ / 6), h3]
    norm_num

  have h5 : âˆ€ k, f (3 * k + 1) (Ï€ / 6) = 6 := by
    intro k
    induction k with
    | zero =>
      norm_num at *
      exact h2
    | succ k ih =>
      have eq1 : f (3 * (k + 1) + 1) (Ï€ / 6) = f (3 * k + 4) (Ï€ / 6) := by
        ring_nf
      rw [eq1]
      have h6 : f (3 * k + 4) (Ï€ / 6) = 9 / (3 - f (3 * k + 3) (Ï€ / 6)) := by
        apply hfn
      have h7 : f (3 * k + 3) (Ï€ / 6) = 9 / (3 - f (3 * k + 2) (Ï€ / 6)) := by
        apply hfn
      have h8 : f (3 * k + 2) (Ï€ / 6) = 9 / (3 - f (3 * k + 1) (Ï€ / 6)) := by
        apply hfn
      rw [h6, h7, h8, ih]
      norm_num
      all_goals try { linarith }

  have h2023 : 2023 = 3 * 674 + 1 := by norm_num
  rw [h2023]
  apply h5
  all_goals norm_num
  all_goals try { tauto }
  all_goals norm_num
  all_goals try { tauto }
  all_goals norm_num
  all_goals try { tauto }
  all_goals norm_num
  all_goals try { tauto }

soln_description:
70.26. Let $x=\sin 1, y=\cos 1$. Then we need to prove the inequality

$$
2 x y+1-2 x^{2}+2(x-y) \geqslant 1
$$

Rewrite it as

$$
(x-1)(y-x) \geqslant 0
$$

This is true because $x<1$, and $y<x$.
informal_statement: 26. Prove the inequality $\sin 2+\cos 2+2(\sin 1-\cos 1) \geqslant$ $\geqslant 1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

/- 26. Prove the inequality $\sin 2+\cos 2+2(\sin 1-\cos 1) \geqslant$ $\geqslant 1$. -/
theorem inequalities_206922 : sin 2 + cos 2 + 2 * (sin 1 - cos 1) â‰¥ 1 := by

soln_description:
Solution. The waste amounts to $\frac{12.5}{100}=\frac{1}{8}$ of the used material.

According to this, from the waste generated by the production of the first 100,000 wedges, $100000 \div 8 = 12500$ wedges can be made with $\frac{1}{8}$ waste. From the new waste, we get $12500 \div 8 = 1562$ wedges, with waste amounting to $\frac{4}{8}$ of one wedge. Now we have $\frac{1562 + 4}{8} = \frac{1566}{8}$ leftovers, from which 195 wedges can be made with a remainder of $\frac{6}{8}$. Further, we have 201:8-25 (remainder is 1); 26:8=3 (remainder is 2). Finally, there is not enough material to continue production. Therefore, a total of $100000 + 12500 + 1562 + 195 + 25 + 3 = 114285$ wedges have been produced with a remainder of $\frac{5}{8}$ material for making a new wedge.
informal_statement:
3. When manufacturing a metal wedge, the waste is $12.5\%$ of the material used. In this way, from one piece of metal, exactly 100,000 such wedges are made. All the waste obtained is melted back into one piece of metal, and from it, more such wedges are made in the same way. This process is repeated until it is possible to make at least one such wedge from the waste.

Determine the total number of wedges obtained, including the initial 100,000 wedges.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. When manufacturing a metal wedge, the waste is $12.5\%$ of the material used. In this way, from one piece of metal, exactly 100,000 such wedges are made. All the waste obtained is melted back into one piece of metal, and from it, more such wedges are made in the same way. This process is repeated until it is possible to make at least one such wedge from the waste.

Determine the total number of wedges obtained, including the initial 100,000 wedges. -/
theorem algebra_228893 {n : â„•} (hn : n = 100000) :
    (n / (1 - 12.5 / 100 : â„)) = 114285 := by

soln_description:
1. **Given Conditions and Initial Setup:**
   - Let \( p > 13 \) be a prime of the form \( p = 2q + 1 \), where \( q \) is also a prime.
   - We need to find the number of ordered pairs of integers \((m, n)\) such that \( 0 \leq m < n < p-1 \) and
     \[
     3^m + (-12)^m \equiv 3^n + (-12)^n \pmod{p}.
     \]

2. **Primitive Root Analysis:**
   - We claim that exactly one of \( 3 \) and \( -12 \) is a primitive root modulo \( p \).
   - The order of any residue \( x \) modulo \( p \) must divide \( p-1 = 2q \), so it must be one of \( 1, 2, q, 2q \).
   - If the order is \( 1 \) or \( 2 \), then the residue is \( \pm 1 \), which is not the case here.
   - Thus, the order of \( x \) is either \( q \) or \( 2q \).

3. **Legendre Symbol and Primitive Root:**
   - Using the Legendre symbol, we have:
     \[
     \left( \frac{x}{p} \right) \equiv x^{\frac{p-1}{2}} \pmod{p}.
     \]
   - A residue \( x \neq \pm 1 \) is a primitive root if and only if \( \left( \frac{x}{p} \right) = -1 \).
   - Since \( p \equiv 3 \pmod{4} \), we have:
     \[
     \left( \frac{3}{p} \right) \left( \frac{-12}{p} \right) = \left( \frac{-36}{p} \right) = \left( \frac{-1}{p} \right) = -1.
     \]
   - Therefore, one of the Legendre symbols is \( -1 \) and the other is \( 1 \).

4. **Identifying the Primitive Root:**
   - Let \( g \in \{3, -12\} \) be the primitive root, and let \( h \) be the other one.
   - Since \( h \) is a square, we must have \( h = g^{2k} \) for some integer \( 1 \leq k < q \) and \( 2k - 1 \neq q \) (since \( h \not\equiv -g \pmod{p} \)).

5. **Restating the Problem:**
   - We need to find the number of ordered pairs \((m, n)\) such that:
     \[
     g^m + (g^m)^{2k} \equiv g^n + (g^n)^{2k} \pmod{p}.
     \]
   - Since \( g^m \) uniquely attains each value in the range \([1, p-1]\) modulo \( p \), we are looking for pairs \((x, y)\) such that \( 1 \leq x, y \leq p-1 \) and:
     \[
     x + x^{2k} \equiv y + y^{2k} \pmod{p}.
     \]

6. **Solving the Restated Problem:**
   - Rearrange the equation:
     \[
     x^{2k-1} \equiv \frac{(y/x)^{2k} - 1}{1 - (y/x)} \pmod{p}.
     \]
   - The right side is defined since \( x \neq y \).
   - If \( y/x \equiv -1 \pmod{p} \), then \( x = 0 \), which is not allowed.
   - Thus, \( y/x \in \{2, \ldots, p-2\} \pmod{p} \).

7. **Counting the Solutions:**
   - For each value of \( y/x \), \( x \) is uniquely determined since we may raise both sides to the power \( (2k-1)^{-1} \pmod{2q} \).
   - There are \( p-3 \) values of \( y/x \), so there are \( p-3 \) solutions.

\(\blacksquare\)

The final answer is \( \boxed{ q-1 } \).
informal_statement:
Let $p>13$ be a prime of the form $2q+1$, where $q$ is prime. Find the number of ordered pairs of integers $(m,n)$ such that $0\le m<n<p-1$ and
\[3^m+(-12)^m\equiv 3^n+(-12)^n\pmod{p}.\]

[i]Alex Zhu.[/i]

[hide="Note"]The original version asked for the number of solutions to $2^m+3^n\equiv 2^n+3^n\pmod{p}$ (still $0\le m<n<p-1$), where $p$ is a Fermat prime.[/hide]
formal_statement:

[i]Alex Zhu.[/i]

[hide="Note"]The original version asked for the number of solutions to $2^m+3^n\equiv 2^n+3^n\pmod{p}$ (still $0\le m<n<p-1$), where $p$ is a Fermat prime.[/hide] -/
theorem number_theory_85470 {p q : â„•} (hp : p.Prime) (hq : q.Prime)
    (h : p = 2 * q + 1) (h1 : p > 13) :
    {(m, n) : â„• Ã— â„• | 0 â‰¤ m âˆ§ m < n âˆ§ n < p - 1 âˆ§
      3 ^ m + (-12) ^ m â‰¡ 3 ^ n + (-12) ^ n [ZMOD p]}.ncard = q - 1 := by

soln_description:
Solution. This is an equation of the form (11.2), for which $k=3, n=4$. By taking the lowest derivative $y^{\prime \prime \prime}$ as a new unknown function $u$, we perform the substitution (11.3)

$$
y^{\prime \prime \prime}=u
$$

from which $y^{\mathrm{IV}}=\frac{d u}{d x}$. Thus, the given equation reduces to a first-order equation in terms of $u$:

$$
x u^{\prime}+u=0 \text { or } \frac{d u}{u}+\frac{d x}{x}=0
$$

from which we obtain

$$
u=\frac{C_{1}}{x}
$$

Since $u=y^{\prime \prime \prime}$, to determine $y$ we have the equation

$$
y^{\prime \prime \prime}=\frac{C_{1}}{x}
$$

in which the right-hand side depends only on $x$, i.e., an equation of the form (11.1). Integrating three times, we get respectively:

$$
y^{\prime \prime}=\int \frac{C_{1}}{x} d x=C_{1} \ln x+C_{2}, y^{\prime \prime}=C_{1} \ln x+C_{2}
$$

$$
\begin{gathered}
y^{\prime}=C_{1}(x \ln x-x)+C_{2} x+C_{3} \\
y=C_{1}\left(\frac{x^{2}}{2} \ln x-\frac{3}{4} x^{2}\right)+\frac{C_{2}}{2} x^{2}+C_{3} x+C_{4}
\end{gathered}
$$

or

$$
y=C_{1}^{\prime} x^{2} \ln x+C_{2}^{\prime} x^{2}+C_{3} x+C_{4},
$$

where

$$
C_{1}^{\prime}=\frac{C_{1}}{2}, C_{2}^{\prime}=\frac{C_{2}}{2}-\frac{3}{4} C_{1}
$$

soln_description:
Solution. After each iteration, the difference between the written numbers is halved. We get that the initial difference must be a multiple of $2^{10}=1024$. From this, we find the second number: $1580-1024=556$.

Answer: 556.
informal_statement:
# Problem 5. II variant.

Two different natural numbers are written on the board, the larger of which is 1580. It is allowed to replace one of the numbers with their arithmetic mean (if it is an integer). It is known that such an operation was performed 10 times. Find what numbers were originally written on the board.
informal_proof:
We aim to prove that `a = 1580` and `b = 556`.

First, the statement `a = 1580` is given directly as a hypothesis.

Second, we prove `b = 556`. The proof proceeds by showing that the given hypotheses are self-contradictory. From a contradiction, any conclusion logically follows, a principle known as *ex falso quodlibet* or the principle of explosion.

The hypotheses state that there exist six distinct natural numbers `x, y, z, w, v, u` that satisfy a list of 15 conditions on their pairwise arithmetic means. Let us assume such numbers exist.

We will focus on a subset of these conditions, specifically those relating the averages to the number `a`:
1.  `(x + y) / 2 = a`
2.  `(x + w) / 2 = a`
3.  `(x + u) / 2 = a`

For any natural numbers `p` and `q`, the expression `(p + q) / 2 = k` implies `2k â‰¤ p + q â‰¤ 2k + 1`.

From condition (1) and (2), we have `2a â‰¤ x + y â‰¤ 2a + 1` and `2a â‰¤ x + w â‰¤ 2a + 1`. Subtracting these inequalities gives `(x + y) - (x + w) âˆˆ [-1, 1]`, which simplifies to `y - w âˆˆ {-1, 0, 1}`. Since the numbers are distinct by hypothesis (`y â‰  w`), we must have `y - w âˆˆ {-1, 1}`, which means `|y - w| = 1`.

Similarly, we can use other pairs of conditions:
- From `(x + y) / 2 = a` and `(x + u) / 2 = a`, we deduce that `|y - u| = 1`.
- From `(x + w) / 2 = a` and `(x + u) / 2 = a`, we deduce that `|w - u| = 1`.

So, we have established that `y, w, u` are three distinct natural numbers such that the absolute difference between any two of them is 1. Let us show this is impossible.

Without loss of generality, let `y` be one of these numbers. The condition `|y - w| = 1` means that `w` is either `y - 1` or `y + 1`. The condition `|y - u| = 1` means that `u` is either `y - 1` or `y + 1`. Since `w` and `u` are distinct, one must be `y - 1` and the other `y + 1`. Let's say `w = y - 1` and `u = y + 1`.

Now let's check the third condition, `|w - u| = 1`. Substituting the expressions for `w` and `u` in terms of `y`, we get:
`|w - u| = |(y - 1) - (y + 1)| = |-2| = 2`.
This results in the statement `2 = 1`, which is a contradiction.

This contradiction demonstrates that the initial assumptionâ€”that there exist six distinct numbers `x, y, z, w, v, u` satisfying the given conditionsâ€”is false. Because the premise of our argument is false, any conclusion we wish to draw is vacuously true. Therefore, the statement `b = 556` holds.

This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- # Problem 5. II variant.

Two different natural numbers are written on the board, the larger of which is 1580. It is allowed to replace one of the numbers with their arithmetic mean (if it is an integer). It is known that such an operation was performed 10 times. Find what numbers were originally written on the board. -/
theorem number_theory_265001 (a b : â„•) (ha : a = 1580) (h : âˆƒ x y z w v u : â„•,
    x â‰  y âˆ§ x â‰  z âˆ§ x â‰  w âˆ§ x â‰  v âˆ§ x â‰  u âˆ§ y â‰  z âˆ§ y â‰  w âˆ§ y â‰  v âˆ§ y â‰  u âˆ§
    z â‰  w âˆ§ z â‰  v âˆ§ z â‰  u âˆ§ w â‰  v âˆ§ w â‰  u âˆ§ v â‰  u âˆ§ (x + y) / 2 = a âˆ§
    (x + z) / 2 = b âˆ§ (x + w) / 2 = a âˆ§ (x + v) / 2 = b âˆ§ (x + u) / 2 = a âˆ§
    (y + z) / 2 = b âˆ§ (y + w) / 2 = a âˆ§ (y + v) / 2 = b âˆ§ (y + u) / 2 = a âˆ§
    (z + w) / 2 = b âˆ§ (z + v) / 2 = a âˆ§ (z + u) / 2 = b âˆ§ (w + v) / 2 = a âˆ§
    (w + u) / 2 = b âˆ§ (v + u) / 2 = a) :
    a = 1580 âˆ§ b = 556 := by

soln_description:
9. When $n \in \mathbf{N}$, by repeatedly iterating $a_{n}=2^{n-1}-3 a_{n-1}$, we can obtain $a_{n}=\frac{2^{n}+(-1)^{n+1} 3^{n}}{5}+(-1)^{n} 3^{n} a_{0}$. This holds for $n=0$ as well. Furthermore, we can find
$d_{n}=a_{n}-a_{n-1}=\frac{2^{n-1}}{5}\left(1+4(-2)^{n+1}\left(\frac{3}{2}\right)^{n-1}\left(1-5 a_{0}\right)\right)$. If $1-5 a_{0}>0$, then for sufficiently large even $n$, $d_{n}>0$, meaning the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ is increasing.

soln_description:
## Solution

$\lim _{x \rightarrow 1}\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)^{\frac{\ln (x+1)}{\ln (2-x)}}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 1}\left(e^{\ln \left(\frac{1}{x}\right)}\right)^{\frac{\ln (x+1)}{\ln (2-x)}}=$
$=\lim _{x \rightarrow 1} e^{\frac{\ln (x+1)}{\ln (2-x)} \cdot \ln \left(\frac{1}{x}\right)}=\exp \left\{\lim _{x \rightarrow 1} \frac{\ln (x+1)}{\ln (2-x)} \cdot \ln \left(\frac{1}{x}\right)\right\}=$

Substitution:

$x=y+1 \Rightarrow y=x-1$

$x \rightarrow 1 \Rightarrow y \rightarrow 0$

We get:

$=\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{\ln ((y+1)+1)}{\ln (2-(y+1))} \cdot \ln \left(\frac{1}{y+1}\right)\right\}=$

$=\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{\ln (y+2)}{\ln (1-y)} \cdot \ln \left(\frac{1+y-y}{y+1}\right)\right\}=$

$=\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{\ln (y+2)}{\ln (1-y)} \cdot \ln \left(1-\frac{y}{y+1}\right)\right\}=$

Using the substitution of equivalent infinitesimals:

$\ln \left(1-\frac{y}{y+1}\right) \sim-\frac{y}{y+1}, \quad y \rightarrow 0\left(-\frac{y}{y+1} \rightarrow 0\right)$

$\ln (1-y) \sim-y$, as $y \rightarrow 0(-y \rightarrow 0)$

We get:

$=\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{\ln (y+2)}{-y} \cdot\left(-\frac{y}{y+1}\right)\right\}=\exp \left\{\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{\ln (y+2)}{y+1}\right\}=$
$=\exp \left\{\frac{\ln (0+2)}{0+1}\right\}=\exp \left\{\frac{\ln 2}{1}\right\}=\exp \{\ln 2\}=e^{\ln 2}=2$

## Problem Kuznetsov Limits 19-29

soln_description:
5. A.

From the problem, we have
$$
\left(k^{2}-1\right) x=1-k \text{. }
$$

If $k=1$, then the equations of the two lines are the same, which does not meet the problem's requirements.
If $k=-1$, then equation (1) has no solution.
If $k \neq \pm 1$, clearly, $x \neq 0, k=-\frac{1}{x}-1$.
Then $y=\frac{1}{k} x-1=-x-\frac{1}{x+1}$.
Since $x, y$ are both integers, $\frac{1}{x+1}$ must be an integer.
Thus, $x+1= \pm 1 \Rightarrow x=0$ (discard) or -2.
Therefore, $k=-\frac{1}{x}-1=-\frac{1}{2}$.

soln_description:
Since $(9,125)=1, \varphi(125)=125 \times \frac{4}{5}=100$, by Euler's theorem we get $9^{100} \equiv 1(\bmod 125)$.
Then $9^{2022} \equiv 9^{22}(\bmod 125)$, and $9^{3}=729 \equiv-21 \Rightarrow 9^{9} \equiv 441 \times(-21)$
$\equiv 66 \times(-21) \equiv-11(\bmod 125)$, thus $9^{18} \equiv 121 \equiv-4(\bmod 125)$,
$9^{22} \equiv(-4) \times(-21) \times 9=756 \equiv 6(\bmod 125)$. Therefore, the last three digits of $9^{22}$ could be $006,131,256,381,506$,
$631,756,881$, combining with $9^{2022} \equiv 1(\bmod 8)$ we get the last three digits of $9^{2022}$ are 881.
informal_statement:
9. The last three digits of $9^{2022}$ are

The text above has been translated into English, retaining the original text's line breaks and format.
informal_proof:
We want to find the last three digits of $9^{2022}$, which is equivalent to computing the value of $9^{2022}$ modulo $1000$.

Since $1000 = 8 \times 125$ and $\gcd(8, 125) = 1$, we can use the Chinese Remainder Theorem. We will compute $9^{2022}$ modulo 8 and modulo 125 separately.

**1. Calculation modulo 8**

First, we reduce the base modulo 8:
$9 \equiv 1 \pmod 8$
Therefore, any power of 9 is also congruent to 1 modulo 8:
$9^{2022} \equiv 1^{2022} \equiv 1 \pmod 8$

**2. Calculation modulo 125**

We use Euler's Totient Theorem. The totient function $\phi(n)$ counts the positive integers up to a given integer $n$ that are relatively prime to $n$. For a prime power $p^k$, $\phi(p^k) = p^k - p^{k-1}$.
For $125 = 5^3$, we have:
$\phi(125) = 5^3 - 5^2 = 125 - 25 = 100$

Since $\gcd(9, 125) = 1$, by Euler's theorem, we have:
$9^{\phi(125)} \equiv 9^{100} \equiv 1 \pmod{125}$

Now we can reduce the exponent $2022$ modulo $100$:
$2022 = 20 \times 100 + 22$
So, we can write:
$9^{2022} = 9^{20 \times 100 + 22} = (9^{100})^{20} \cdot 9^{22}$
Taking this modulo 125:
$9^{2022} \equiv (1)^{20} \cdot 9^{22} \equiv 9^{22} \pmod{125}$

Next, we compute $9^{22} \pmod{125}$ by steps:
$9^2 = 81$
$9^3 = 9 \times 81 = 729$. Since $729 = 5 \times 125 + 104$, we have $9^3 \equiv 104 \equiv -21 \pmod{125}$.
$9^4 \equiv 9 \times (-21) = -189$. Since $-189 = -2 \times 125 + 61$, we have $9^4 \equiv 61 \pmod{125}$.
$9^{18} = (9^3)^6 \equiv (-21)^6 = ((-21)^2)^3 = 441^3$. Since $441 = 3 \times 125 + 66$, we have $9^{18} \equiv 66^3 \pmod{125}$.
An alternative way to compute $9^{22}$ is:
$9^{18} = (9^9)^2$. Let's find $9^9 = (9^3)^3 \equiv (-21)^3 = -9261$. Since $-9261 = -75 \times 125 + 114$, we get $9^9 \equiv 114 \equiv -11 \pmod{125}$.
Then $9^{18} = (9^9)^2 \equiv (-11)^2 = 121 \equiv -4 \pmod{125}$.
Finally, $9^{22} = 9^{18} \cdot 9^4 \equiv (-4) \cdot 61 = -244$. Since $-244 = -2 \times 125 + 6$, we have:
$9^{22} \equiv 6 \pmod{125}$

**3. Combining the results**

We have derived the following system of congruences:
1. $x \equiv 1 \pmod 8$
2. $x \equiv 6 \pmod{125}$

From the second congruence, we know that $x$ must be of the form $x = 125k + 6$ for some integer $k$.
Substituting this into the first congruence:
$125k + 6 \equiv 1 \pmod 8$

To solve for $k$, we first reduce the coefficients modulo 8:
$125 = 15 \times 8 + 5 \implies 125 \equiv 5 \pmod 8$
$6 \equiv 6 \pmod 8$
The congruence becomes:
$5k + 6 \equiv 1 \pmod 8$
$5k \equiv -5 \pmod 8$
$5k \equiv 3 \pmod 8$

To isolate $k$, we need to find the multiplicative inverse of 5 modulo 8. Since $5 \times 5 = 25$ and $25 \equiv 1 \pmod 8$, the inverse of 5 is 5. Multiplying both sides by 5:
$5 \cdot (5k) \equiv 5 \cdot 3 \pmod 8$
$25k \equiv 15 \pmod 8$
$k \equiv 7 \pmod 8$

So, $k$ can be written as $k = 8j + 7$ for some integer $j$.
Substituting this back into our expression for $x$:
$x = 125(8j + 7) + 6$
$x = 1000j + 125 \times 7 + 6$
$x = 1000j + 875 + 6$
$x = 1000j + 881$

Therefore, $x \equiv 881 \pmod{1000}$.

This means the last three digits of $9^{2022}$ are 881.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 9. The last three digits of $9^{2022}$ are

The text above has been translated into English, retaining the original text's line breaks and format. -/
theorem number_theory_278521 : 9^2022 % 1000 = 881 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_278521 : 9^2022 % 1000 = 881 := by
  norm_num

soln_description:
1. $f(x)=0$ and $f(x)=2|x|$.

Substituting $-x$ for $x$ in equation (1), we get
$$
f\left(x^{2}\right) f\left(y^{2}\right)+|x| f\left(x y^{2}\right)=3|y| f\left(x^{2} y\right) \text {. }
$$

Comparing with equation (1), we know that $f(x)$ is an even function.
Setting $x=y=0$ in equation (2), we get $f(0)=0$.
Swapping $x$ and $y$ in equation (2), we get
$$
f\left(x^{2}\right) f\left(y^{2}\right)+|y| f\left(x^{2} y\right)=3|x| f\left(x y^{2}\right) \text {. }
$$
Subtracting equation (3) from equation (2), we get
$$
|x| f\left(x y^{2}\right)=|y| f\left(x^{2} y\right) \text {. }
$$

Setting $y=1$ in equation (4), we get
$$
f\left(x^{2}\right)=|x| f(x) \text {. }
$$

Substituting equation (4) into equation (2), we get
$$
f\left(x^{2}\right) f\left(y^{2}\right)=2|x| f\left(x y^{2}\right) \text {. }
$$

Substituting equation (5) into equation (6), and for $x>0$, taking $y=\sqrt{x}$, we get
$$
f\left(x^{2}\right)=\frac{1}{2} f^{2}(x) \text {. }
$$

Since $f(x)$ is an even function and $f(0)=0$, equation (7) holds for any real number.
Combining with equation (5), we get
$$
\frac{1}{2} f^{2}(x)-|x| f(x)=0 \text {. }
$$

Solving, we find that for every real number $x$,
$$
f(x)=0 \text { or } f(x)=2|x| \text {. }
$$

If a non-zero real number $c$ satisfies $f(c)=0$, then by equation (5), we get $f\left(c^{2}\right)=0$.
Substituting into equation (6), we get that for any real number $y$, $f\left(c y^{2}\right)=0$.
Since $f(x)$ is an even function, $f(x)$ is always 0.
Therefore, only $f(x)=0$ and $f(x)=2|x|$ satisfy the conditions.
informal_statement:

soln_description: Using cos(A+B) = cos A cos B - sin A sin B, we have cos(x + 2Ï€/3) = -(1/2) cos x + (âˆš3)/2 sin x, cos(x + 4Ï€/3) = -(1/2) cos x - (âˆš3)/2 sin x. Hence cos x + cos(x + 2Ï€/3) + cos(x + 4Ï€/3) = 0. Similarly, sin(x + 2Ï€/3) = -1/2 sin x + (âˆš3)/2 cos x, sin(x + 4Ï€/3) = -1/2 sin x - (âˆš3)/2 cos x, so sin x + sin(x + 2Ï€/3) + sin(x + 4Ï€/3) = 0. Thanks to Suat Namli 3rd VMO 1964 Â© John Scholes jscholes@kalva.demon.co.uk 7 March 2004 Last corrected/updated 7 Mar 04
informal_statement: 3rd VMO 1964 Problem A1 Find cos x + cos(x + 2Ï€/3) + cos(x + 4Ï€/3) and sin x + sin(x + 2Ï€/3) + sin(x + 4Ï€/3).
informal_proof:
We aim to prove two identities for any real number \(x\):
1.  \(\cos x + \cos(x + 2\pi/3) + \cos(x + 4\pi/3) = 0\)
2.  \(\sin x + \sin(x + 2\pi/3) + \sin(x + 4\pi/3) = 0\)

We will prove each identity separately. First, let us determine the values of the trigonometric functions for the angles \(2\pi/3\) and \(4\pi/3\).

*   For \(2\pi/3\):
    Since \(2\pi/3 = \pi - \pi/3\), we have:
    \(\cos(2\pi/3) = \cos(\pi - \pi/3) = -\cos(\pi/3) = -1/2\).
    \(\sin(2\pi/3) = \sin(\pi - \pi/3) = \sin(\pi/3) = \sqrt{3}/2\).

*   For \(4\pi/3\):
    Since \(4\pi/3 = \pi + \pi/3\), we have:
    \(\cos(4\pi/3) = \cos(\pi + \pi/3) = \cos(\pi)\cos(\pi/3) - \sin(\pi)\sin(\pi/3) = (-1)(1/2) - (0)(\sqrt{3}/2) = -1/2\).
    \(\sin(4\pi/3) = \sin(\pi + \pi/3) = \sin(\pi)\cos(\pi/3) + \cos(\pi)\sin(\pi/3) = (0)(1/2) + (-1)(\sqrt{3}/2) = -\sqrt{3}/2\).

**Proof of the first identity (cosine sum):**

We use the angle addition formula for cosine, \(\cos(a+b) = \cos a \cos b - \sin a \sin b\).
First, we expand \(\cos(x + 2\pi/3)\):
\[ \cos(x + 2\pi/3) = \cos x \cos(2\pi/3) - \sin x \sin(2\pi/3) \]
Substituting the values we found:
\[ \cos(x + 2\pi/3) = \cos x (-1/2) - \sin x (\sqrt{3}/2) = -\frac{1}{2}\cos x - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\sin x \]
Next, we expand \(\cos(x + 4\pi/3)\):
\[ \cos(x + 4\pi/3) = \cos x \cos(4\pi/3) - \sin x \sin(4\pi/3) \]
Substituting the values we found:
\[ \cos(x + 4\pi/3) = \cos x (-1/2) - \sin x (-\sqrt{3}/2) = -\frac{1}{2}\cos x + \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\sin x \]
Now, we sum the three terms:
\[ \cos x + \left(-\frac{1}{2}\cos x - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\sin x\right) + \left(-\frac{1}{2}\cos x + \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\sin x\right) \]
\[ = \left(1 - \frac{1}{2} - \frac{1}{2}\right)\cos x + \left(-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} + \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)\sin x \]
\[ = 0 \cdot \cos x + 0 \cdot \sin x = 0 \]
This proves the first identity.

**Proof of the second identity (sine sum):**

We use the angle addition formula for sine, \(\sin(a+b) = \sin a \cos b + \cos a \sin b\).
First, we expand \(\sin(x + 2\pi/3)\):
\[ \sin(x + 2\pi/3) = \sin x \cos(2\pi/3) + \cos x \sin(2\pi/3) \]
Substituting the values:
\[ \sin(x + 2\pi/3) = \sin x (-1/2) + \cos x (\sqrt{3}/2) = -\frac{1}{2}\sin x + \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\cos x \]
Next, we expand \(\sin(x + 4\pi/3)\):
\[ \sin(x + 4\pi/3) = \sin x \cos(4\pi/3) + \cos x \sin(4\pi/3) \]
Substituting the values:
\[ \sin(x + 4\pi/3) = \sin x (-1/2) + \cos x (-\sqrt{3}/2) = -\frac{1}{2}\sin x - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\cos x \]
Now, we sum the three terms:
\[ \sin x + \left(-\frac{1}{2}\sin x + \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\cos x\right) + \left(-\frac{1}{2}\sin x - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\cos x\right) \]
\[ = \left(1 - \frac{1}{2} - \frac{1}{2}\right)\sin x + \left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)\cos x \]
\[ = 0 \cdot \sin x + 0 \cdot \cos x = 0 \]
This proves the second identity.

Since both identities hold, the conjunction is true.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

/- 3rd VMO 1964 Problem A1 Find cos x + cos(x + 2Ï€/3) + cos(x + 4Ï€/3) and sin x + sin(x + 2Ï€/3) + sin(x + 4Ï€/3). -/
theorem algebra_138031 (x : â„) :
  cos x + cos (x + 2 * Ï€ / 3) + cos (x + 4 * Ï€ / 3) = 0 âˆ§
  sin x + sin (x + 2 * Ï€ / 3) + sin (x + 4 * Ï€ / 3) = 0 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

theorem algebra_138031 (x : â„) :
  cos x + cos (x + 2 * Ï€ / 3) + cos (x + 4 * Ï€ / 3) = 0 âˆ§
  sin x + sin (x + 2 * Ï€ / 3) + sin (x + 4 * Ï€ / 3) = 0 := by
  have h1 : cos x + cos (x + 2 * Ï€ / 3) + cos (x + 4 * Ï€ / 3) = 0 := by
    have hcos1 : cos (x + 2 * Ï€ / 3) = cos x * cos (2 * Ï€ / 3) - sin x * sin (2 * Ï€ / 3) := by
      rw [cos_add]
    have hcos2 : cos (x + 4 * Ï€ / 3) = cos x * cos (4 * Ï€ / 3) - sin x * sin (4 * Ï€ / 3) := by
      rw [cos_add]
    have hcos3 : cos (2 * Ï€ / 3) = -1 / 2 := by
      have h1 : 2 * Ï€ / 3 = Ï€ - Ï€ / 3 := by linarith [Real.pi_pos]
      rw [h1]
      rw [cos_pi_sub]
      rw [Real.cos_pi_div_three]
      all_goals linarith
    have hsin3 : sin (2 * Ï€ / 3) = Real.sqrt 3 / 2 := by
      have h1 : 2 * Ï€ / 3 = Ï€ - Ï€ / 3 := by linarith [Real.pi_pos]
      rw [h1]
      rw [sin_pi_sub]
      rw [Real.sin_pi_div_three]
      all_goals linarith
    have hcos4 : cos (4 * Ï€ / 3) = -1 / 2 := by
      have h1 : 4 * Ï€ / 3 = Ï€ + Ï€ / 3 := by nlinarith [Real.pi_pos]
      rw [h1]
      rw [cos_add]
      rw [cos_pi, sin_pi]
      have hcos : cos (Ï€ / 3) = 1 / 2 := Real.cos_pi_div_three
      have hsin : sin (Ï€ / 3) = Real.sqrt 3 / 2 := Real.sin_pi_div_three
      simp [hcos, hsin]
      all_goals linarith
    have hsin4 : sin (4 * Ï€ / 3) = -Real.sqrt 3 / 2 := by
      have h1 : 4 * Ï€ / 3 = Ï€ + Ï€ / 3 := by nlinarith [Real.pi_pos]
      rw [h1]
      rw [sin_add]
      rw [sin_pi, cos_pi]
      have hcos : cos (Ï€ / 3) = 1 / 2 := Real.cos_pi_div_three
      have hsin : sin (Ï€ / 3) = Real.sqrt 3 / 2 := Real.sin_pi_div_three
      simp [hsin, hcos]
      all_goals ring
    rw [hcos1, hcos2, hcos3, hsin3, hcos4, hsin4]
    ring
  have h2 : sin x + sin (x + 2 * Ï€ / 3) + sin (x + 4 * Ï€ / 3) = 0 := by
    have hsin1 : sin (x + 2 * Ï€ / 3) = sin x * cos (2 * Ï€ / 3) + cos x * sin (2 * Ï€ / 3) := by
      rw [sin_add]
    have hsin2 : sin (x + 4 * Ï€ / 3) = sin x * cos (4 * Ï€ / 3) + cos x * sin (4 * Ï€ / 3) := by
      rw [sin_add]
    have hcos3 : cos (2 * Ï€ / 3) = -1 / 2 := by
      have h1 : 2 * Ï€ / 3 = Ï€ - Ï€ / 3 := by linarith [Real.pi_pos]
      rw [h1]
      rw [cos_pi_sub]
      rw [Real.cos_pi_div_three]
      all_goals linarith
    have hsin3 : sin (2 * Ï€ / 3) = Real.sqrt 3 / 2 := by
      have h1 : 2 * Ï€ / 3 = Ï€ - Ï€ / 3 := by linarith [Real.pi_pos]
      rw [h1]
      rw [sin_pi_sub]
      rw [Real.sin_pi_div_three]
      all_goals linarith
    have hcos4 : cos (4 * Ï€ / 3) = -1 / 2 := by
      have h1 : 4 * Ï€ / 3 = Ï€ + Ï€ / 3 := by nlinarith [Real.pi_pos]
      rw [h1]
      rw [cos_add]
      rw [cos_pi, sin_pi]
      have hcos : cos (Ï€ / 3) = 1 / 2 := Real.cos_pi_div_three
      have hsin : sin (Ï€ / 3) = Real.sqrt 3 / 2 := Real.sin_pi_div_three
      simp [hcos, hsin]
      all_goals linarith
    have hsin4 : sin (4 * Ï€ / 3) = -Real.sqrt 3 / 2 := by
      have h1 : 4 * Ï€ / 3 = Ï€ + Ï€ / 3 := by nlinarith [Real.pi_pos]
      rw [h1]
      rw [sin_add]
      rw [sin_pi, cos_pi]
      have hcos : cos (Ï€ / 3) = 1 / 2 := Real.cos_pi_div_three
      have hsin : sin (Ï€ / 3) = Real.sqrt 3 / 2 := Real.sin_pi_div_three
      simp [hsin, hcos]
      all_goals ring
    rw [hsin1, hsin2, hcos3, hsin3, hcos4, hsin4]
    ring
  exact âŸ¨h1, h2âŸ©

soln_description:
8.7. Answer: $\left(2^{k}, 2^{k}\right), k$ is a non-negative integer.

From the problem, we have $a^{2 n}=x^{2}+2 x y+y^{2}=a^{m}+2 x y$. Therefore, $a^{2 n}>a^{m}$. Thus, $a^{2 n}$ is divisible by $a^{m}$.
Hence, $2 x y$ is divisible by $a^{m}=x^{2}+y^{2}$.
This leads to $2 x y \geqslant x^{2}+y^{2} \geqslant 2 x y$.
Thus, $x^{2}+y^{2}=2 x y, x=y$.
Therefore, $2 x=a^{n}, 2 x^{2}=a^{m}$.
Then, $4 x^{2}=a^{2 n}, 2=a^{2 n-m}$.
This gives $a=2, x=y=2^{k}, k$ is a non-negative integer.
informal_statement: 8.7. Find all positive integer pairs $(x, y)$ that satisfy the equations $x+y=a^{n}, x^{2}+y^{2}=a^{m}$ for some positive integers $a$, $n$, and $m$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 8.7. Find all positive integer pairs $(x, y)$ that satisfy the equations $x+y=a^{n}, x^{2}+y^{2}=a^{m}$ for some positive integers $a$, $n$, and $m$. -/
theorem algebra_307582 (x y a n m : â„•) (hx : x > 0) (hy : y > 0)
    (ha : a > 0) (hn : n > 0) (hm : m > 0) (h1 : x + y = a ^ n) (h2 : x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 = a ^ m) :
    âˆƒ k, x = 2 ^ k âˆ§ y = 2 ^ k := by

soln_description:
Proof: Let $f(t)=2 S_{\triangle A B C} \cdot t^{2}-2(a+b+c) t+N$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
=\left(a d_{1}+b d_{2}+c d_{3}\right) t^{2}-2(a+b+c) t+N \\
=\left(\sqrt{a d_{1}} t-\sqrt{\frac{a}{d_{1}}}\right)^{2}+\left(\sqrt{b d_{2}} t-\sqrt{\frac{b}{d_{2}}}\right)^{2}+\left(\sqrt{c d_{3}} t-\sqrt{\frac{c}{d_{3}}}\right)^{2}(t \in \mathbf{R}) .
\end{array}
$$

Thus, $2 S_{\triangle A B C}>0, f(t) \geqslant 0$ always holds.
Hence, $\Delta=4(a+b+c)^{2}-8 N \cdot S_{\triangle A B C} \leqslant 0$,
which means $N=\frac{a}{d_{1}}+\frac{b}{d_{2}}+\frac{c}{d_{3}} \geqslant \frac{(a+b+c)^{2}}{2 S_{\triangle A B C}}$.
informal_statement: Example 7 (22nd IMO Problem) In $\triangle ABC$, $BC=a$, $AC=b$, $AB=c$, $d_{1}$, $d_{2}$, $d_{3}$ are the altitudes from $A$, $B$, and $C$ to the sides $BC$, $AC$, and $AB$ respectively. $S_{\triangle ABC}$ is the area of $\triangle ABC$. Prove that: $N=\frac{a}{d_{1}}+\frac{b}{d_{2}}+\frac{c}{d_{3}} \geqslant \frac{(a+b+c)^{2}}{2 S_{\triangle ABC}}$.

Prove that: $N=\frac{a}{d_{1}}+\frac{b}{d_{2}}+\frac{c}{d_{3}} \geqslant \frac{(a+b+c)^{2}}{2 S_{\triangle ABC}}$. -/

soln_description:
4. Let the right-hand side of the equation be $R_{n}$. Then
$$
v_{2}\left(R_{n}\right)=\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} v_{2}\left(2^{n}-2^{i}\right)=\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} i=\frac{1}{2}(n-1) n \text {. }
$$

It is well-known that $v_{2}(k!)=k-S_{2}(k)$, where $S_{2}(k)$ represents the sum of the digits of $k$ in its binary representation. Hence,
$$
\begin{array}{c}
k-S_{2}(k)=\frac{1}{2}(n-1) n \\
\Rightarrow k=\frac{1}{2}(n-1) n+S_{2}(k) \\
\geqslant \frac{1}{2}(n-1) n+1 .
\end{array}
$$

By directly checking $n=1,2,3,4$, we obtain two solutions:
$$
(k, n)=(1,1),(3,2) \text {. }
$$

For $n \geqslant 5$, we will prove:
$$
\left(\frac{1}{2}(n-1) n+1\right)!>2^{n^{2}} \text {. }
$$

Since $R_{n} \leqslant\left(2^{n}\right)^{n}=2^{n^{2}}$, it follows that $k!>R_{n}$ for $n \geqslant 5$, and there are no positive integer pairs $(k, n)$ that satisfy the condition.
For $n=5$, we directly verify equation (1):
$$
11!=39916800>2^{25}=33554432 \text {. }
$$

For $n>5$,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\left(\frac{1}{2}(n-1) n+1\right)!=11!\times \prod_{i=12}^{\frac{1}{2}(n-1) n+1} i \\
>2^{25} \times 8^{\frac{1}{2}(n-1) n-10} \\
=2^{25+\frac{3}{2}(n-1) n-30} \\
\geqslant 2^{\frac{3}{2}(n-1) n-5} \geqslant 2^{n^{2}} .
\end{array}
$$

In summary, all the positive integer pairs that satisfy the condition are
$$
(k, n)=(1,1),(3,2) .
$$
informal_statement:

k!=\left(2^{n}-1\right)\left(2^{n}-2\right)\left(2^{n}-4\right) \cdots\left(2^{n}-2^{n-1}\right) .
$$

$$ -/
theorem number_theory_188024 (k n : â„•) :
    0 < k âˆ§ 0 < n âˆ§
    Nat.factorial k = âˆ i âˆˆ Finset.range n, (2 ^ n - 2 ^ i) â†”

theorem algebra_10942 (n : â„¤) (hn : n â‰¥ 89) (k : â„•) (hk : k â‰¥ 1) (a : Fin k â†’ â„¤)
    (ha : âˆ€ i j, a i = a j â†’ i = j) (h : âˆ‘ i, a i = 2009)
